title: Friday, 1st September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Ah! It is working. Good morning, welcome, hi.

BE11:06am

This is Markets Live, of course. FT Alphaville's daily thing with the stuff.

BE11:06am

Paul's off somewhere. Dunno where. Somewhere.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Which means I get to pick the image.

BE11:07am

And since it's the first of the month, I'm going for something nice and cheery.

BE11:07am

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Looks like the Twitter logo.

BE11:07am

Flies along, gets into a wee bit of an inconsequential tangle, then rights itself and flies off again.

BE11:08am

That's an accurate representation of the average user's Twitter experience, I'd suggest.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

It's not the Twitter logo though.

BE11:08am

It's the Suboxone logo.

BE11:08am

The wee tangle in the middle represents heroin additiction.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

You can see it used in context here: https://www.suboxone.com/

BE11:09am

That's Indivior's site, that's full of handy advice for heroin addicts who want to cure their heroin addiction by taking more heroin.

BE11:09am

Though when those addicts are Googling for said advice, they're also likely to run up against this kind of thing.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

BE11:10am

So anyway, this is all apropos of Indivior losing its second patent trial over Suboxone film

BE11:10am

Which is 80% of its revenues, to remind.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Dr Reddy can't launch immediately because it needs FDA clearance .......... however, the FDA seems to have accelerated its processing of ANDAs lately.

BE11:12am

(See the most recent update on the FDA site. I'd find the link myself but I'm busy typing.)

BE11:12am

There's also the possibility that Indivior can defend its market via appeal.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

But I'm not 100% sure it has the goodwill to carry that.

BE11:13am

Because of this kind of thing: http://www.thedail...-of-heroin-addicts

BE11:13am

........ so, the Indivior investment case is even more about RBP-6000, the one-a-month heroin solution.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Potentially approved by end November, though no guarantees.

BE11:14am

Here comes Jefferies to explain,

BE11:15am

Indivior has announced that the US District Court for Delaware has
found the asserted claims of U.S. Patent Nos. 8,017,150; 8,603,514; 8,900,497 valid, but that
Dr. Reddy's does not infringe any asserted claims of those patents, and that Watson (Actavis)
and Par do not infringe the asserted claim of the '497 Patent. The Court has also issued
a separate ruling denying Watson's and Par's motions to reopen the Court's June 2016
judgment finding that their respective proposed generic products infringe valid claims of the
'514 Patent. Therefore, the Court's ruling enjoining marketing approval and sale of Watson's
and Par's proposed generic products until the expiration of the '514 Patent in 2024E remains
in place, but they can now pursue their respective appeals. Indivior is also likely to have
increased difficulty successfully defending its IP against future ANDA filers.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

(@BornCynic: yep.)

BE11:15am

Pending appeal, which we
estimate can take 12-18 months, Suboxone Film could face generic competition by early
2019 assuming DRL waits for the appeals process to play out. Dr. Reddy’s has a target FDA
action date 1Q' 18E where it may receive tentative approval (pending 180 days). As Actavis’
180-day exclusivity is predicated on winning its litigation, we see a scenario where DRL
could potentially launch before Actavis, or Actavis does a deal with DRL to enter the market
earlier. Given the potential liability to launch at risk and its track-record in these scenarios, on
balance we suspect DRL will wait for a resolution. Indivior has prepared various contingency
plans in the event of an “at risk” launch given the challenges it would present the business.

BE11:16am

In our report published on
11 August, we had updated our LV downside if Indivior was to lose the case at 290p. This had
assumed that the patents were invalid and that Indivior loses its appeals. Although today’s
update is disappointing, in our view the situation is not as bad as this scenario would suggest
given: 1) the appeals process can take 12-18m; 2) Indivior has a strong balance sheet; 3) if
the depot launches in 1Q’18E, there is potentially a year to convert stable patients onto the
new formulation thus reducing the market opportunity of the film generic if the timings are
as per our base case; and 4) the scenario doesn’t consider any change in Indivior's business
model – given INDV’s fixed and sizeable cost base (esp. SG&A) there is the potential for
significant savings if needs be to weather any profitability impact.

11:16 am
Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 260.50, down 156.1 (-37.47%), High: 287.70, Low: 246.50, Volume: 5.28m
BE11:17am

Just scanning through the sellside. Jefferies was one of several buyers here.

BE11:21am

(@Xanthine: the central test of a generic getting approved is equivalence. As I understand it, the main risk is around switching formulations mid treatment -- ie, to a generic from branded or vice versa -- and even then it's extremely unlikely.)

11:22 am
BE11:22am

...... which seems rather brave given the rally it's had on everything working out okay, and the US providing the safe regulatory environment because it needs to fix its skag problem by any means necessary.

BE11:22am

Stifel, for instance.

BE11:22am

Clearly the district court ruling that Dr
Reddy's generic Suboxone film does not infringe Indivior's patents increases the risk of an
early generic launch. Longer term Indivior's value rests with RBP-6000 and we continue
to believe this will achieve sales of $707m by 2021E. Our 400p target price places Indivior
on a 2019E P/E of 20x, the year of trough earnings.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Feels like risk-reward got a bit skewed going into this. And I think we may have said as much a week or two ago.

undefined
BE11:24am

So ........................

11:24 am
BE11:25am

........................ FTSE going nowhere in particular.

BE11:25am

Most of the emails I've had this morning are about US gasoline shortages, which I'm struggling to get overly interested in.

BE11:26am

Not a lot around in corporate.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

I guess we could do a hot money wrap-up ....

BE11:28am

Starting with Gemalto results overnight. They're garbage, but they're no worse than the garbage that had already been expected.

BE11:28am

Perhaps more significantly .....

11:28 am
BE11:28am

*GEMALTO DOESN'T PLAN TO SELL LARGE UNIT OF THE COMPANY: CEO

BE11:28am

*GEMALTO MAY SELL OR STOP SMALL, NON-CORE ACTIVITIES, CEO SAYS

BE11:29am

Otherwise, we get an unchanged H2 outlook and €50m of cost savings. What we don't get is a bid, from anyone, in any form.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Though I'm sure that hasn't dissuaded the amateur punters from tossing on about how things are poised to happen.

BE11:30am

UBS incoming.

BE11:31am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: 1) Cost saving plans (€50m) have been initiated and are expected to provide a €15m benefit this year but there is no increase in terms of action on cost; 2) Double-digit declines y-o-y in Q2 in Payments (-21%) and Mobile SIM (-19%) and will remain challenging in H2; 3) One bright spot was machine-to-machine growing 15% y-o-y in Q2 and expected to accelerate in H2; 4) Cash from ops was weaker than UBSe due to working capital coming in lower than we had assumed (€118m vs. UBSe €183m).
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Unchanged. Gemalto is guiding H2 '17 sales to be flat y-o-y (including benefit of 3M Identity management business) and profit from operations to between €200m and €230m (as at the July pre-announcement). We believe consensus is aligned with guide.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Visibility is clearly challenging in Gemalto's end markets but we believe unchanged H2 guide could provide reassurance though valuation not cheap on 16x '18E P/E.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Meanwhile in France, we have more protectionist noises from Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire.

BE11:33am

Still insistent about defending strategic companies

BE11:33am

Which makes Danone look a problematic target.

11:34 am

..... Next on the hot money circuit, we have NETS

BE11:35am

https://www.ft.com...-a352-e46f43c5825d

11:36 am

BE11:36am

https://www.ft.com...-9084-d0c17942ba93

BE11:37am

And an approximate price of $5bn, which would be nearly nil premium on its current value.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

And finally in hot money corner .....

BE11:05am

The system was a bit slow to drag itself up by the bootstraps this morning, apologies for the late start.

BE11:38am

Let me see if I have that to hand.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

....................... arg, Computer running painfully slow. Sorry for the dead air.

BE11:41am

Bottom Line: Recent discussions with several MEDACorp KOLs
have been balanced with respect to Omadacycline oral-only skin
infection results: specialists, because of high nausea/vomiting
(30%/17%) rates, are quick to quell thoughts that Omadacycline
could be the next Z-pack or Levofloxacin, however, all docs see
a role for the product in otherwise healthy outpatients that are
treatment refractory. This is consistent with how we’ve modeled
the Omadacycline outpatient opportunity (low single-digit % share
- $250MM in 2023 revenue), and, importantly, enthusiasm for the
drug’s role as an IV-to-oral stepdown in the inpatient setting remains
solid. It is through this lens that we’ve contemplated a recent
Bloomberg report (8/23) that PRTK, after receiving takeover interest,
is considering strategic options. Whether or not there is true
strategic interest in Paratek is unknowable, though we did highlight
the company as one of our picks as a possible takeover target
in our prior P&A piece earlier this yr (LINK). As we've conducted
additional research, we remain positive on the stock as - even after
a recent run - we don't believe that lofty expectations for the drug
are a pre-requisite for upside. With the caveat that any deal is driven
by a handful of specific, often nuanced factors, based on three
prior transactions in the antibiotic space (using Trius as in our
view the best comp, page 5) along with our ests in skin, pneumonia
and urinary tract infection (UTI - risk-adjusted at 30%), we think a
takeout price in the high $30s could be reasonable if an acquisition
were to occur. Along with our research we've made some tweaks to
our model, including a higher probability for UTI based on recent oralonly results (now 30%, from 15%), increased expenses, and a slightly
more conservative revenue multiple in our valuation (based on our M&A
analysis). These changes have a small negative impact on our Price
Target, putting our hybrid DCF/revenue multiple analysis at ($34/$37)
underlying our per share valuation of ~$36. Reiterate OP on PRTK

BE11:41am

Sorry for the lumpy formatting.

11:41 am
undefined
BE11:43am

There are more hot money stocks, of course. There always are. Quite a few US food companies, for instance. But we can't backtest the info in realtime and it would be irresponsible to report it blind.

BE11:43am

So, we say cheerio to hot money corner.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@fjp73: go on.)

BE11:44am

Who wanted HSBC on the pubs?

Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 667.00, down 22.5 (-3.26%), High: 673.50, Low: 652.00, Volume: 808.47k
11:44 am
J D Wetherspoon PLC (JDW:LSE): Last: 1,085, down 6.95 (-0.64%), High: 1,093, Low: 1,073, Volume: 48.32k
Marston's PLC (MARS:LSE): Last: 115.20, down 0.3 (-0.26%), High: 117.10, Low: 113.50, Volume: 655.71k
Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 253.80, up 5.9 (+2.38%), High: 253.80, Low: 245.90, Volume: 52.69k
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Straightforward note: we're not drinking enough.

BE11:46am

Limited attractions in the pub companies. They aren’t especially cheap and they
face earnings risk. In this note we show how valuation support is limited and
conclude that consumer weakness may now be showing through and, combined with
cost increases, this could hurt earnings for some of the operators.

BE11:46am

Sales are sluggish and under threat. Anecdotally, a downturn may already be under way. Pubs talk of eating/ drinking out being an “affordable treat” that would not be badly impacted in a consumer downturn. Maybe that’s true, though macro level data suggest that spend was hit badly during the last recession, even if like-for-likes at the big pubcos weren’t. Companies must also try to offset higher costs through higher pricing, which may be difficult: only JDW looks to have clear pricing power, in our view, though M&B could benefit from its reinvestment programme.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

......... which spins us back to Restaurant Group's statement yesterday.

BE11:48am

The buried aspect of Restaurant Group's attempts at a turnaround are that it's pretty much the sector leader and it's cutting prices aggressively.

BE11:48am

The competition is only doing, what, 0.2% LFL?

11:48 am
BE11:48am

How do they respond? I imagine they also cut prices.

BE11:48am

Nothing happens in a vacuum.

BE11:49am

Back to HSBC.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Beware of soothing noises around costs. Although disclosure has begun to improve, some operators (Greene King, M&B) have aggressive mitigation plans. These aren’t always clearly defined, leaving us uncertain that they can be achieved.

BE11:49am

A more negative stance on the sector. We can’t be sure of a consumer downturn, but do worry about the continued increase in costs and the ease with which this can be mitigated. Operators have already struggled with this even in a benign consumer environment. We don’t see obvious valuation support, and think downgrades will drive share price weakness. We downgrade our rating on Greene King to Reduce (from Hold) on concerns over its cost outlook in particular. We think that JD Wetherspoon (downgrade to Hold) is best placed to trade through the weakness, though the strong share price performance means it’s no longer cheap in the circumstances (Hold). We remain Hold on Marston’s and M&B.

BE11:50am

And a couple of charts.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

BE11:52am

Also interesting:

11:52 am

BE11:57am

Oh, and Clare Smyth on the food stand at 1pm. She's the best chef you've never heard of.

11:57 am

BE11:58am

Get yourself along. What else will you be doing with tomorrow?

BE11:58am

11:58 am
undefined
BE11:59am

(@Airborne: you say that like I don't know.)

BE12:00pm

Nearly done. NFP in a bit.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Tesco mentioned on the right. Haven't heard anything.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 183.55, up 2.65 (+1.46%), High: 183.97, Low: 180.90, Volume: 5.54m
BE12:01pm

Deutsche pushing.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The UK is a pioneer market for online grocery. But it is showing signs of maturity. This report
shows that penetration in key age demographics has peaked, with market growth materially
slowing in the past two years. Our in-depth comparison of the cost structure for delivering an
online order at Ocado (SELL. mature pure online) vs. Tesco (BUY, store based online) shows that
the incumbents are cost advantaged vs. challenger warehouse models. Pending maturity in the
UK, and our analysis of population density, suggests that online may cap out in the US at 4%.

BE12:02pm

(@Lefevre: it's very much an FT Weekend joint. No Alphaville presence.)

BE12:02pm

....... and into the exec sum:

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Given our view of the likely scale of the online grocery market, we believe that
store-based retailers are cost advantaged vs. challenger warehouse models
such as Amazon or Ocado, due to purchasing scale, distribution and delivery.
We take a detailed look at Ocado, the world’s largest pure online grocery
retailer, operating out of the UK. Specifically, we conclude that after 15 years
of operations, we do not believe that its automated picking model exhibits a
cost advantage in fulfillment vs. store based retailers. As such, delivery cost is
the key differentiator and it is less expensive to deliver from a dense store
network than a handful of fulfillment centres or spokes. We re-iterate our Sell
on Ocado and our Buy on Tesco.

BE12:03pm

Amazon’s acquisition of Whole Foods has re-ignited interest in Ocado, and

some believe that its licensing business could benefit from incumbent store-
based food retailers looking for an online solution. We believe that Ocado’s

automated warehouse model has limited appeal, offering no cost advantage
on fulfillment and being disadvantaged on cost of delivery in the majority of
cases. Its front-end software and 15 years of experience have value but we
expect the fee income from licensing deals will ultimately disappoint investors,
reflecting a front-end software solution rather than the automated fulfillment
solution, in which Ocado has invested significantly.

BE12:03pm

Ocado (£1.7bn mkt cap) trades at 1.2x 18E EV/sales, 61x 18E EV/EBIT and 71x
18E PE vs. 2.0x, 81x and 62x at Amazon. Tesco (£15bn market cap) trades at
0.3x 18E EV/Sales, 11.2x 18E EV/EBIT and 15.0x 18E PE vs. a sector average of
0.4x, 10.6x, 15.0x.

12:03 pm
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 305.30, down 4.5 (-1.45%), High: 309.80, Low: 303.30, Volume: 625.48k
undefined
BE12:04pm

ROTR, thanks for flagging Lucy's article today. Absolutely worth your time: https://www.ft.com...-8bb1-5ba57d47eff7

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

Last month I visited the Ark teacher training summer school, where most of the group is being trained — alongside much younger trainees. (A minority will be training with me at Mossbourne Community College in Hackney, with a few more at Holland Park School and elsewhere.) I watched the first session in which everyone had to play an ice-breaking game called backpack bingo.

I suppressed my habitual aversion to such pranks, and looked around the room to see the Now Teach trainees obediently shouting “bingo!” along with the younger ones. They were getting on with it. And so must I.

Watching them, I realised what I am giving up to train to be a teacher, as well as income, time and autonomy: a life-long tendency towards cynicism. This has served me well for 32 years as a journalist, but now I fear that it is going to get in the way.

BE12:07pm

(@BornCynic: I guess usernames have nominative determination.)

undefined
12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

And we're done. Slightly slow this morning, for which I apologise. Next week will be better. Probably.

BE12:08pm

See you Monday.

BE11:38am

Paratek. There's a Leerink note around talking about a takeout price in the high $30s.
